Authors: Nan Zhang, Dongqing Yang, Qirong Shen, Ruifu Zhang
Title:
Genomic and root exudates regulated transcriptomic analysis
revealed the rhizosphere adaption and plant beneficial characteristics
of rhizobacteria Bacillus amyloliquefaciens SQR9
Abstract:
Background: Bacillus amyloliquefaciens SQR9 (SQR9 in
abbreviation) is a beneficial plant-associated bacterium with
outstanding biocontrol activity and the ability to promote plant growth.
Root exudates are known to play important roles in plant-microbe
interactions. To explore the plant beneficial characteristics and
rhizosphere interactions of SQR9, complete genome sequence and
transcriptomic analysis response to maize root exudates were performed.
Results: The complete genome sequence of B. amyloliquefaciens SQR9
revealed numerous functional genes related to suppression of plant
pathogens and promotion of plant growth, indicating the potential for
production of novel anti-bacterial chemicals. Root exudates stimulated
biofilm formation of SQR9 in liquid culture. The RNA-sequencing based on
transcriptional profiling of SQR9 response to maize root exudates under
static conditions indicated that most of the regulated genes belonged to
intermediary metabolism, ATP-binding cassette (ABC) transporters, cell
motility and chemotaxis, biofilm formation and synthesis of secondary
metabolites with antimicrobial action. It was found that plenty of the
significant genes were involved in rhizosphere adaptation and plant
beneficial. Conclusions: The complete genome sequence and transcriptome
analysis reported here provide useful information for understanding
plant-rhizobacteria interactions and hence for promoting the
agricultural applications of this plant growth-promoting rhizobacteria
(PGPR) strain, such as applied as bio-organic fertilizer or a biocontrol
agents for suppression of soil-borne diseases.
